items.prompt: How do you say the symbol '@' in an email address?
items.explanation: In email addresses, '@' is pronounced 'at'.

items.prompt: How do you say the symbol '.' in an email address?
items.explanation: In email addresses, '.' is pronounced 'dot'.

items.prompt: Choose the correct spelling of the number '0' in a phone number context:
items.explanation: In phone numbers, 0 can be said as 'zero' or 'oh'.

items.prompt: What does 'Double seven' mean in a phone number?
items.explanation: 'Double' is used when a number is repeated twice.

items.prompt: Complete the sentence: 'Can you ______ your name, please?'
items.explanation: 'Spell' means to say the letters of a word one by one.

items.prompt: Which letter is pronounced /eɪ/ in English?
items.explanation: The letter 'A' is pronounced /eɪ/.

items.prompt: Which letter is pronounced /iː/ in English?
items.explanation: The letter 'E' is pronounced /iː/.

items.prompt: Which letter is pronounced /aɪ/ in English?
items.explanation: The letter 'I' is pronounced /aɪ/.

items.prompt: In 'info-work@gmail.com', what is the symbol '-'?
items.explanation: The symbol '-' is called a hyphen or a dash.

items.prompt: In 'sales_office@company.com', what is the symbol '_'?
items.explanation: The symbol '_' is called an underscore.

items.prompt: How do you say '912 345'?
options: Nine hundred twelve, three hundred forty-five
items.explanation: Phone numbers are usually dictated digit by digit.

items.prompt: Identify the correct way to say 'john.doe@net.uk':
options: John point doe at net point uk
John dot doe at net dot uk
John period doe at net period uk
John full stop doe at net full stop uk
items.explanation: We use 'dot' for '.' in email addresses.

items.prompt: Which letter sounds like the word 'you'?
items.explanation: The letter 'U' is pronounced /juː/, which sounds like 'you'.

items.prompt: Which letter sounds like the word 'eye'?
items.explanation: The letter 'I' is pronounced /aɪ/, which sounds like 'eye'.

items.prompt: Which of these is a 'last name'?
items.explanation: 'Smith' is a common last name (surname).

items.prompt: How do you spell 'OFFICE'?
items.explanation: OFFICE is spelled O, double F, I, C, E.

items.prompt: What is 'area code'?
options: A secret code for the door
The first numbers of a phone number for a specific region
items.explanation: The area code identifies a specific geographic region in a phone system.

items.prompt: If someone says 'Oh' in a phone number, they mean:
items.explanation: In phone numbers, the digit 0 is often called 'oh'.

items.prompt: Which is the correct spelling for 'B'?
items.explanation: The letter B is pronounced /biː/.

items.prompt: Which letter is often confused with 'G' in pronunciation?
items.explanation: G /dʒiː/ and J /dʒeɪ/ are often confused by learners.

items.text: Complete the email address: info [@] company.com (at)
items.explanation: The symbol '@' means 'at'.

items.text: Spell the word 'Job': [J] - [O] - [B]
items.explanation: The spelling of Job is J-O-B.

items.text: My phone number is 554 210. In English: Double [five] four, two, one, zero.
items.explanation: We use 'double' before the repeated number.

items.text: To ask for a spelling, we say: 'How do you [spell] your name?'
items.explanation: 'Spell' is the verb used to ask for letters.

items.text: The symbol '.' in www.google.com is called a [dot].
items.explanation: In web and email addresses, '.' is called a dot.

items.text: Spell 'EMAIL': E - [M] - [A] - [I] - [L]
items.explanation: The spelling of EMAIL is E-M-A-I-L.

items.text:
A: What is your phone number?
B: It's [zero] - seven - four.
items.explanation: 'Zero' is the standard way to say 0.

items.text: The symbol '_' is an [underscore].
items.explanation: The low line symbol is called an underscore.

items.text:
A: Can you spell your last name?
B: Yes, it's SMITH: S - M - [I] - T - H.
items.explanation: The missing letter in SMITH is I.

items.text: The hyphen symbol looks like this: [-]
items.explanation: The hyphen is the short horizontal line '-'.

items.prompt: Match the symbol name with its character:
items.explanation: Common email and web symbols.

items.prompt: Match the phone number part with its English reading:
items.explanation: Standard ways to dictate numbers.

items.prompt: Match the spelling to the word:
items.explanation: Basic office vocabulary spelling.

items.prompt: Match the letters with their pronunciation sounds:
items.explanation: Vowel sounds in the English alphabet.

items.prompt: Match the question with the response:
items.explanation: Common contact information exchanges.

items.prompt: Match the number reading with the digits:
items.explanation: Reading groups of numbers.

items.prompt: Match the office objects with their spelling:
items.explanation: Basic vocabulary spelling practice.

items.prompt: Match the email components:
items.explanation: Structure of an email address.

items.prompt: Match the alphabet categories:
items.explanation: Different types of characters used in contact info.

items.prompt: Match the spelling request with the situation:

pairs.definition: Can you spell your last name?
How do you spell the street?

items.explanation: Practical use of spelling and clarification.

items.prompt: What do you say after someone says their name and you didn't catch the letters?
items.explanation: 'How do you spell that?' is the natural follow-up to hearing a name.

items.prompt: Which of these email addresses is written correctly?
items.explanation: The standard format is user@provider.domain.

items.prompt: If you hear 'Double zero', you write:
items.explanation: 'Double' means two of the following number.

items.prompt: How do you spell 'USA'?
items.explanation: These are the sounds for the letters U, S, and A.

items.prompt: In English, we say telephone numbers ______.
items.explanation: Digit by digit is the standard way to dictate phone numbers.

items.prompt: Which letter sounds like 'tea'?
items.explanation: The letter T is pronounced /tiː/, which sounds like 'tea'.

items.prompt: Which letter sounds like 'bee'?
items.explanation: The letter B is pronounced /biː/, which sounds like 'bee'.

items.prompt: In 'www.work.org', what is '.org'?
items.explanation: We use 'dot' for websites too.

items.prompt: A: 'Is it hyphen?' B: 'No, it's ________.' ( _ )
items.explanation: The low line _ is an underscore.

items.prompt: How do you spell 'WEB'?
items.explanation: WEB is spelled W-E-B.

items.text: Spell 'ADMIN': A - [D] - [M] - [I] - [N]
items.explanation: Spelling of ADMIN.

items.text: The letter 'H' is pronounced [aitch].
items.explanation: H is pronounced 'aitch'.

items.text: Phone number: 0800 123. 'Oh - eight - oh - [oh] - one - two - three'.
items.explanation: 0 can be said as 'oh'.

items.text: Complete: 'My email address is mark [at] yahoo.com.'
items.explanation: When speaking an email, '@' is said as 'at'.

items.text: The word for '-' in a URL is [hyphen].
items.explanation: Hyphen is the technical term for '-'.

items.text:
Name: Alice Rogers
Email: alice_r@office.com
Phone: 011 558 990
items.explanation: The email uses an underscore '_', not a hyphen '-'.

items.text:
Name: Alice Rogers
Email: alice_r@office.com
Phone: 011 558 990

questions.prompt: How do you say the phone number correctly?

items.explanation: Both using digit-by-digit or 'double' are correct.

items.text:
Name: Alice Rogers
Email: alice_r@office.com
Phone: 011 558 990
items.explanation: Rogers is the last name.

items.text: Message: 'Call me at 077 441.'
items.explanation: There is a double seven (77) and a double four (44).

items.text: Email: support.desk@tech-service.co.uk

questions.prompt: How many dots are in this email?

items.explanation: There are three dots: after support, after tech-service, and after co.

items.text:
A: 'What is your email?'
B: 'It is sales@company.com.'
A: 'Is that S-A-L-E-S?'
B: 'Yes, that's right.'

questions.prompt: Does A know how to spell 'sales'?

items.explanation: A spelled it correctly and B confirmed it.

items.text:
Contact: Dr. Robert Brown
Phone: 020 7946 0011

questions.prompt: How do you say the last 4 digits?

items.explanation: All these variations are used in English.

items.text: Note: 'Meeting with Mr. P. Higgins'.

questions.prompt: How do you spell the last name?

items.explanation: You can say each letter or use 'double'.

items.text: Email: HR_Department@global.net

questions.prompt: Is there a hyphen in the email?

items.explanation: There is an underscore '_', but no hyphen '-'.

items.text:
Business Card: 'Sam Wilson - CEO'.
Sam spells his name: S-A-M.
items.explanation: S-A-M is the correct spelling for Sam.

items.prompt: Translate into English: 'Mi correo es info@work.com.'
items.modelAnswer: My email is info at work dot com.
items.explanation: Translating email symbols into spoken English.

items.prompt: Write the spelling of 'ADMIN' letter by letter.
items.explanation: Practice spelling administrative vocabulary.

items.prompt: Translate into English: '¿Cómo se deletrea su nombre?'
items.modelAnswer: How do you spell your name?
items.explanation: The standard question for asking for spelling.

items.prompt: Write this phone number in words: 0771.
items.modelAnswer: Zero double seven one (or Oh double seven one).
items.explanation: Using 'double' for repeated numbers.

items.prompt: Translate: 'Guion bajo'
items.explanation: The technical name for the '_' symbol.

items.prompt: Translate: 'Punto'
items.explanation: The name for the '.' symbol in emails.

items.prompt: Translate: 'Arroba'
items.explanation: The name for the '@' symbol.

items.title: Contact Details
items.transcript: My email is support@office.com. That is S-U-P-P-O-R-T at office dot com.

questions.question: What is the email address?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'support at office dot com'.

items.title: Phone Number
items.transcript: Can you call me at 020 7741? That is zero two zero, double seven four one.

questions.question: How do you spell the name?
